drug.name: Hydroxyamphetamine
drug.description: Hydroxyamphetamine is a derivative of amphetamines. Hydroxyamphetamine is intended mainly as local eye drops for diagnostic purposes. It is indirect sympathomimetic agent which cause dilation of the eye pupil before diagnostic test. Among the minor side effects from its use are: change in color vision, difficulty seeing at night, dry mouth, headache, increased sensitivity of eyes to sunlight, muscle stiffness or tightness and temporary stinging in the eyes. The main use of hydroxyamphetamines as eye drops is the diagnosis of Horner's syndrome which is characterized by nerve lesions.

link.title: American Academy of Ophthalmology - Horner syndrome Article

drug.indication: Mydriatic agent (eye pupil dilatation) for diagnosis of ophthalmic nerve lesions.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Hydroxyamphetamine hydrobromide is an indirect acting sympathomimetic agent which causes the release of norepinephrine from adrenergic nerve terminals, resulting in mydriasis.
drug.metabolism: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).
drug.absorption: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).
drug.protein-binding: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).
drug.route-of-elimination: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).
drug.volume-of-distribution: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).
drug.clearance: Intended for local use only (ophthalmic use).

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as amphetamines and derivatives. These are organic compounds containing or derived from 1-phenylpropan-2-amine.

category.category: Serotonergic Drugs Shown to Increase Risk of Serotonin Syndrome

drug-interaction.name: Caffeine
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Hydroxyamphetamine is combined with Caffeine.
